abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Forestry Research
            Education and Extension Project is rated as satisfactory,
            sustainability as likely, institutional development impact
            as substantial, Bank performance as satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance as satisfactory. The lessons learned
            from the project include: 1) Openness to proposed extension
            of closing dates by Bank management can be desirable. 2) The
            provision of adequate Bank supervision budget was essential
            to the success of the project. 3) Design of a project
            involving multiple implementing agencies should not rely on
            overall coordination by a national ministry, unless that
            ministry has already demonstrated its capacity for such
            coordination. 4) Good financial management requires the
            active involvement of a financial management specialist
            throughout the project cycle, the full participation of
            financial officers of all implementing agencies as well as
            the project-wide coordination entity in cost estimation and
            budget preparation and processing, ongoing arrangements for
            training and handover as needed to accommodate staff
            turnover, and attention to and accountability for quality
            financial management by government throughout implementation.
